questions.text: Which of the following histamine receptors are presynaptic autoreceptors?
questions.solution:
H3 histamine receptor is a presynaptic autoreceptor.

H3 receptors are predominantly presynaptic and are present in basal ganglia, hippocampus, and cerebral cortex. They function as autoreceptors inhibiting histamine release from the neuron. H3 receptors are also found postsynaptically but their function is not known.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be seen on the administration of an H3 receptor agonist?

choices.text: Inhibition of H1 receptor induced wakefulness
Increase in H2 mediated gastric secretion

questions.solution:
H3 receptor agonist decreases H2 mediated gastric secretion.

H3 receptors are presynaptic inhibitory autoreceptors on histaminergic neurons. H3 receptor agonists decrease the release of histamine and have actions similar to that of antihistamines. 

Normally, histamine increases gastric secretion by acting through the H2 receptor in the stomach. H3 receptor agonist decreases histamine release and hence, decreases H2 receptor-mediated gastric secretion.

Options A and C: H1 receptor stimulation by histamine in the CNS causes wakefulness, and at the bronchus causes bronchoconstriction. Therefore H3 receptor agonists by decreasing histamine release inhibit H1 receptor-induced wakefulness and bronchoconstriction.

Option D: H3 receptors are also presynaptic heteroreceptors on various neurons and their activation can decrease noradrenergic, serotoninergic, cholinergic and glutaminergic transmission. A decrease in noradrenergic transmission in atria can result in a negative chronotropic effect.

questions.text: You are about to prescribe an antihistamine to a patient with allergic rhinitis. You wish to prescribe a second-generation drug as they cause fewer side effects. Which of the following will you not choose?
questions.solution:
Clemastine is a first-generation antihistamine.

H1 antagonists are classified into 2 generations: 

First-generation antihistamines - They have a strong sedative property and also have an antimuscarinic function. They include:

  • Doxepin
  • Clemastine, Diphenhydramine, Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Pheniramine, Chlorpheniramine, Dexchlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Hydroxyzine, Cyclizine, Meclizine, Buclizine, Cinnarizine

Second-generation antihistamines - They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Olopatadine
  • Fexofenadine, Loratadine, Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine
  • Azelastine
  • Mizolastine
  • Ebastine
  • Rupatadine

questions.text: A highway truck driver has presented with profuse rhinorrhea and sneezing. Which of the following drugs will you prefer to prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
The truck driver is suffering from allergic rhinitis and fexofenadine can be prescribed to him. This is preferred as it is a second-generation antihistamine having minimal/no sedative effects as it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier easily.

Pheniramine, promethazine, and hydroxyzine are first-generation antihistamines which should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers because they are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier easily and cause sedation. 

Highly sedative first-generation antihistamines:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine

questions.text: A patient presents to you with difficulty in writing and performing fine movements. On examination, he has a pill-rolling resting tremor. He has been on treatment with haloperidol for the past 12 years. Which of the following antihistamines would you prefer to prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
The scenario points towards a diagnosis of drug-induced Parkinsonism due to long-term intake of haloperidol. Promethazine is the preferred antihistamine as it has the strongest anticholinergic (muscarinic blocking) activity among the given options.

Drug-induced Parkinsonism is caused by drugs that have D2 dopamine antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics (e.g. haloperidol). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring balance.

First-generation H1 antagonists have anticholinergic properties, while second-generation H1 antagonists do not have anticholinergic properties.

H1 antagonists having high anticholinergic activity are as follows:

  • Promethazine 
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Pheniramine

questions.text: A patient having persistent allergic rhinitis is on treatment with intranasal steroids. You wish to add an antihistamine to his treatment regimen. He requests an intranasal preparation. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Azelastine is an antihistamine which has an intranasal preparation for allergic rhinitis.

Olopatadine and azelastine are the second generations antihistaminics available as intranasal (nasal spray) preparations for allergic rhinitis. They have good topical activity.

Intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) remain the preferred monotherapy for persistent allergic rhinitis (AR). However, additional studies support the additive benefit of combination treatment with INCS and intranasal antihistamines in AR. For patients receiving INCS, an intranasal decongestant may be added to the treatment for upto 4 weeks.

questions.text: Which among the following antihistaminic drugs has additional platelet-activating factor antagonistic property?
questions.solution:
Rupatadine is an antihistaminic drug that has additional platelet activating factor antagonistic property and is indicated in allergic rhinitis.

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) is involved in the pathophysiology of allergic rhinitis, asthma, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A patient with cystic fibrosis was found to be underweight during his regular check-up. He complains of low appetite and you decide to prescribe an appetite-stimulating agent. Which antihistaminic drug can you prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has an appetite-stimulating effect and has been used to promote weight gain in poor eaters.

The appetite-stimulating effect may be due to the H1 antihistaminic effect and an effect on growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: A patient has presented to your OPD complaining of hearing loss following an attack of vertigo. He says he has had similar episodes in the past. You decide to prescribe him betahistine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The scenario given in the question likely points to a diagnosis of Meniere's disease. Betahistine is a selective H1 agonist used in this condition.

It causes vasodilation in the inner ear which improves circulation. Hence, it is used to treat vertigo in Meniere's disease.

questions.text: A patient with narcolepsy has been prescribed tiprolisant. How does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Tiprolisant is a selective H3 receptor - inverse agonist.

Tiprolisant promotes wakefulness, improves cognitive functions (e.g., enhances memory, learning, and attention), and reduces food intake. It is also known as pitolisant, and it reduces excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy in adults with narcolepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution: Promethazine is used for motion sickness. It is an antihistaminic agent that acts as an antagonist of H1 receptors. It also has central anticholinergic activity that is responsible for its antiemetic action.
